title: stackcrunch.io launch article

blocks.text: In the 2018 HackerRank Survey, StackOverflow was voted as the ubiquitous platform of choice for learning by developers of all ages. It comes as no surprise that the immense wealth of knowledge on Q&A platforms help a great number of budding developers to find their footing in the field of software development.

If we look closely at the usual progression of any beginner to become a good developer, one can notice this unique pattern that a lot of us can relate to. Before starting with a new technology, quite a few of us (devs) read up those ReadMes, Docs and start on our development journey. But, let’s face it, docs are sometimes too dense or lack examples or are incomplete (sorry but RTFM doesn’t always help). That is when we look for some beginner guides or youtube tutorials. Luckily the web is overflowing with such stuff — “How to get started with X in Y mins?”. And undoubtedly that does help us get going. But, wait for a second, does it end here? No, that would be too soon to raise “Mission Accomplished” Banner.

Now that we have been able to learn how to sit in the boat, we must realize that there is a good length of the journey still left before we build something spectacular. It is after this initiation, that the developers face real challenges and have to take a huge number of decisions, do a lot of patches, debugging & optimizations.


📷

This workflow is quite analogous to how a parent takes care of their children. When a child gets sick, a parent rushes to the doctor. Doc asks for symptoms and recommends a cure. Similarly, when a developer discovers a bug, he reaches out to Google (Doctor), types in the issue (symptoms), and Google gives a long list of related SO links (medicines).

But, a good number of doctors usually also recommend taking a healthy dose of vitamins to boost immunity & reduce the number of revisits. Our web lacks those essential vitamins in a high enough number or at least visibility & awareness are limited due to the distributed nature of such information.
So, how would you define a vitamin in this context?

A vitamin would be a concise article/video accompanied by examples/demo taking the reader through the whole journey of building something cool while showcasing how you tackled some interesting problems through practical real-world solutions along the way.

This is where StackCrunch comes in, to fill this void, to bring developers to one place where they can learn from exemplary development stories rooted in real-world practical solutions.

We will always face problems, there is no way of getting away from them. But, we hold the choice over the type & quality of those problems. If we can increase the awareness and retention of solutions to simpler issues, we can increase the attention towards more difficult ones on Q&A platforms. That would lead to an overall increase in the quality of the products we deliver.

Great experiences are easier to remember. One would have higher retention of the awesome talk they listened to, a great article they read in the evening rather than getting over with a frustrating issue through a quick fix. It comes as no surprise that even the great Dan Abramov would tweet something like that :P

StackCrunch has immense respect for the StackExchange communities & is built to show gratitude to the amazing work put forward by its developers, maintainers, & most importantly the Contributors.
something
StackCrunch will be launched soon in early access mode. Share, Tweet & Subscribe to be the first one to know about it :)

summary: this is a failed project's sad story.. uwain uwain uwain.... :'(((
